comment._content: AG is likely Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. The "Mrs" is unclear to me. He divorced his first wife ca. 1909, and remarried 1911. He died on the Lusitania.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The widow was born Margaret Emerson, herself an heiress of the Bromo Seltzer fortune: "[Isaac Edward] Emerson's daughter Margaret married at 18 to Dr. Smith Hollins McKim. They became social leaders in New York's high society. But in 1910 she brought a sensational divorce suit against her husband, claiming he beat her in drunken rages. She remarried in 1911, this time to Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt I, one of the wealthiest men in America having inherited the bulk of his father's fortune in 1889. They had two sons, Alfred Gwynne Jr. and George. Tragically, while traveling to England on business, Alfred Sr. heroically lost his life in the sinking of RMS Lusitania by torpedo in 1915. Margaret inherited her husband's fortune (as well as the bulk of her father's fortune when he died). One son from this marriage, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt II went on to become one of the driving forces behind thoroughbred racing in America. Margaret married two more times, both ending in divorce. In 1931 she legally resumed her maiden name." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captain_Isaac_Edward_Emerson Margaret Emerson's obituary from January, 1960: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D06E4DD1138E333... comment._content: Agreed. Good job! The address was 1021 Park Avenue. It was Vincent Astor who had lived there the year before Mrs. AGV took it in September, 1915. books.google.com/books?id=3EtIAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA675&i... The current building was erected in 1929. In 2002, the New York Times published an interesting historical account of the 20th Century buildings at 1021 Park Avenue and vicinity: www.nytimes.com/2002/08/18/realestate/streetscapes-1021-p...
